text.p: Following are some of the
main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified
these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Chances of a re-start of bankrupt aircraft maker Fokker
mount as Dutch parties involved sign memorandum of
understanding. (p1)
- Housing boom made strong contribution to the substantial
growth in consumer spending in 1996. (p1)
- Government debt is falling at an unusually fast rate, the
central planning bureau CPB says. (p1)
- Dutch distributors of gas and electricity have boosted
their productivity by 20 percent in the past two years. (p1)
- Plastics concern Schuttersveld reports 20
percent profits growth in 1996 to Dfl 30.2 mln. (p3)
- Unions and employers in the building trade reach pay and
conditions CAO agreement. (p3)
- Dairy cooperative Campina talks with Nutricia
about taking over a dairy products unit in Wegrow,
Poland. (p3)
- Dredging concern Boskalis expects 12-20 percent
profits increase in 1997 after a weak 1996. (p5)
VOLKSKRANT
- Chemicals concern Akzo Nobel considers
experiment with 36- hour working week unsuccessful. (p1)
- Unions FNV and CNV and some humanitarian organisations
demand clarification from ABN Amro bank on its role in
the court case against Indonesian union leader Pakpahan. (p2)
- Textile producer Gamma's 's net profit is
suffering from impopularity of curtains. (p2)
- Rabobank thinks that Germany will meet EMU criteria in
DE TELEGRAAF
- Cabinet is concerned about high mortgages people get due
to low interest rates. (p3)
- Royal Dutch Airlines/KLM and Schiphol Airport
interested in extending Germany's Berlin-Hamburg High-Speed rail
towards Schiphol. (p9)
- Philips Electronics is to introduce a re-writable
CD recorder in Europe next month. (p29)
- Dairy cooperative Campina's 1996 result lower due to
pressured prices on the Belgian, Dutch and German markets. (p29)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Royal Dutch/Shell's Chinese projects gain
momentum as Chinese Shell staff member was released from prison.
- ABN Amro Rothschild becomes global coordinator Europe for
the privatisation of Australia's telecom company Telstra. (p14)
TROUW
- Investments by pension funds and the seven largest
insurers grew 100 bn guilders to 900 bn guilders in 1996. (p7)
